Posts.Content: montrial wrote: I am currently undergoing treatment for LE and will soon need to order compression sleeves, gauntlet and/or glove.  Can anyone dealing with LE give me some guidance as to which brands, etc. you have found through your experience to be the best?  Do you replace them every 6 months?  Should I start out with a pair so I have one to use while washing the other?  Do you have to wear these ALL THE TIME -- day and night??  Has anyone seen a video which shows how to message and wrap your arm that you feel is helpful?  As you can tell -- I am clueless about LE and would appreciate your input regarding any aspect of dealing with LE you think would be helpful.  Many thanks!!!  Montrial Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2010 03:24AM montrial wrote: Binney4 -- I guess I was foolish to try to rush to a selection of a night sleeve.  I had thought one could order with a short turnaround time like compression sleeves.  My research on step up-speak out was informative and brought me to the realization it was a much more involved process.  My therapist has ordered me two compression sleeves (Juzo - soft) and I will get them on Friday morning with instruction.  I guess I will just need to wrap my arm at night (ugh) until I am able to sort through the different night sleeve options.  One option is the Tribute by Solaris.  It is a custom fit foam type night sleeve (no latex).  The other is the "Measure Up" Arm Sleeve by Circaid.  It is an adjustable (velcro flaps), non elastic, assured gradient compression sleeve with a foam liner made of cotton, nylon and lycra (no latex).  The Tribute sounds more comfortable and easier to use, whereas the Measure Up sounds more sturdy and is adjustable should arm size change.  Circaid also make a sleeve called "Silhouette" which is a foam, fluid directed, type sleeve.  It is only warrantied for 6 mo rather than 12 mo as the others and appears to be more "flimsy".  Do you have any knowledge of these products?  If so, could you give me your evaluation of them?  If you are familiar with another night sleeve you think would be better, please let me know so I can consider them.  The costs of the ones I mentioned seem to range from $650 to $700, so I need to feel fairly comfortable that I have done my research before selecting and ordering.  Once again, thank you for lending your ear and knowledge to those of us in need.  Montrial
Posts.Title: New at Lymphedeme montrial kcshreve

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2010 08:05AM - edited Jun 22, 2010 08:09AM by montrial Thanks everyone for your input!  One question -- compression garments:  I read on the "step up - speak out" site that one should NOT wear the same compression sleeve for night as used for day.  I asked my therapist about that as I thought I had understood him to say you do.  He again said you could wear the same one at night as used for day.  Could someone with experience or knowledge regarding this advise me further please.  Also, if a different type recommended for night, what type would you suggest, or would you recommend wrapping every night? Thanks so much.  Montrial

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 11:26PM montrial wrote: HELP!!!!!  I am going on vacation next week (30th Anniversary).  Need to order a night sleeve but don't know which is best.  Any suggestions/direction  would be greatly appreciated so hopefully I can get it ordered and in before our trip.  Many, many thanks!  Montrial

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2010 03:08AM montrial wrote: (To all -- thanks again for your prompt and informative responses!) Estepp:  I, like you, was just diagnosed in June of this year.  I was in early stage with swelling over the 2 cm.  I have been in therapy with a certified lymphedema therapist since June 7th.  I was measured for my compression sleeve last Friday and will change from wrap to sleeve at my appointment this Friday.  My therapist originally told me I could wear the Jovi soft sleeve both day and night.  Thanks to this site (and it's wonderful participants) I became more educated regarding LE.  I was the one who told my therapist I could not wear the Jovi sleeve at night, but rather needed a special night sleeve.  I directed him to the step up-speak out site.  I feel he is a good and caring therapist for the massage, wrap, instruction, etc., but is lacking in overall knowledge.  He was just certified last year, though he has been treating LE patients for 8 years.  One of my concerns is he is not a "fitter" and does not know a "fitter" to recommend.  He measured my arm and ordered the Jovi soft sleeve for me, and he is the one who will check the fit.  I hope I am in "good" hands, because it sounds like the fit of these garments is especially important.  The Solaris custom fit garment sounds very nice and comfortable.  However, I have three dogs and I worry about them damaging the sleeve accidently with a paw/nail.  I noted they do not warranty against this type of damage.  Do you feel the material for the Solaris if fairly durable??  I, again like you, had noticed some slight swelling in my arm but was in denial and did not opt to go to a therapist until a visit with my oncologist who noticed the swelling and told me I needed to go for treatment.  Now, as I read more and more about LE, I am learning about the seriousness of the condition.  I want to do the appropriate things to keep it under control, but at the same time want to be sure the information I base my at home care on is "sound".  I wondered if I could wear a compression sleeve during the day and utilize a night sleeve only if I notice slight swelling.  My therapist says NO -- wear the night sleeve every night, so that is what I plan on doing.  I have not had any swelling in my hand, so I will be trying a sleeve without a gauntlet to see how it works.  To think I thought once I was through the chemo/surg/radiation with good results I would be "home free".  It seems there is always something.  Now I feel I am becoming paranoid:  someone sent me an email the other day with symptoms of ovarian cancer and I felt I have most of them.  I plan to wait and talk to my oncologist at my next recheck, which is in August, should they persist.  I do think doctors need to do more to inform their breast cancer patients of their risk for LE -- if mine had, I would have been more vigilant.  My prayers and best wishes for you all as you continue facing your own battles.  Meantime -- thanks a gain for being there for me.  Montrial
Posts.Title: New at Lymphedeme montrial kcshreve

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2010 05:02AM montrial wrote: FaithandFifty -- Am I understanding that one is not to wear a compression sleeve during the day WITHOUT a gauntlet or glove?  I had not heard that.  Montrial

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2010 01:44AM montrial wrote: Thanks to all for your posts.  I do have one other question.  The therapist I am seeing is certified for LE trmt.  However, I don't recall where his certification certificate was from.  How does one know if they have a "good" therapist?  I live in Knoxville, TN, and the UT (University of TN) Physical Therapy site does not mention lymphedema.  I opted to go with Farragut Physical Therapy because they did have the LE "certified" therapist and it was more conveniently located as I have to go early morning before work.  They are only open Mon-Wed-Fri, so treatment is only every other day.  They did say they would schedule on Tue/Thu if needed.  I have only been provided with one set of wraps and got the impression I would not need them much after my sessions with them were completed.  They did say I would need to wear a compression garment -- I thought they said day and night.  I will clarify that at my next visit.  Anyone out there who has gone through LE treatment in Knoxville?  If so, where and any recommendations?  Otherwise, any suggestions as to how I might determine if I am in the right place for treatment?  Knowing you are there to help education me and respond to my questions gives me a feeling of relief and peace of mind.  Thanks ever so much!  I will check into the site suggested for additional info.  Montrial
